questions.question: Which of the following is the most common type of shock:
questions.explanation: Hypovolemic shock is the most common type of shock, typically caused by severe blood or fluid loss, resulting in inadequate circulation and reduced blood volume.

questions.question: A patient is treated for hypovolemic shock following a motor vehicle collision. Which of the following is not a compensatory mechanism that is anticipated to occur in this patient?

options.C: Reduced perfusion to the GI tract

questions.explanation: The compensatory mechanism in shock reduces the perfusion to the skin, muscle, and gastrointestinal tract and not to the kidney. As shock progresses, the body's cardiovascular and endocrine compensatory responses reduce the blood flow to non-essential organs by vasoconstriction. This occurs in order to preserve preload and flow to the kidneys, lungs, and brain.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, he had multiple injuries over his body and was found to be in Class II hemorrhagic shock. The percentage of blood loss would be between:
questions.explanation: The percentage of blood loss in Class II hemorrhagic shock is 15-30%, which amounts to a loss of 750-1500 mL of blood. The Class II hemorrhagic shock is considered as a mild shock with a heart rate of more than 100. It is associated with orthostatic hypotension, and the patient is usually anxious at this stage.

questions.question: Following a road traffic accident, a 23-year-old man presents with breathlessness. On examination, he has hypotension and distended neck veins. On auscultation, muffled heart sounds are heard. What is this condition primarily associated with?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of Beck's triad (hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds) is seen in cardiac tamponade. Shock due to cardiac tamponade is primarily an example of obstructive shock. Obstructive shock is characterized by a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of the cardiac filling of the left and/or right sides of the heart, which in turn leads to a fall in cardiac output. Common causes of obstructive shock include: cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, and massive pulmonary embolus or air embolus. Cardiogenic shock is due to primary failure of the heart to pump blood. It may be due to myocardial depression as a result of infarction, cardiomyopathy, or blunt myocardial injury. Patients with cardiac tamponade may eventually develop cardiogenic shock as the myocardium is stressed against the obstruction.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man sustained a spinal cord injury as a result of a road traffic accident. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg. All of the following findings can be seen in the patient except?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario of the presence of hypotension associated with the spinal cord injury is suggestive of neurogenic shock. It is associated with bradycardia and not tachycardia. Neurogenic shock refers to reduced tissue perfusion due to loss of vasomotor tone to peripheral arterial beds. Neurogenic shock is usually secondary to spinal cord injuries due to vertebral body fractures of the cervical or high thoracic region that disrupts the sympathetic regulation of peripheral vascular tone. Loss of vasoconstrictor impulses results in increased vascular capacitance, decreased venous return, and decreased cardiac output. Neurogenic shock disruption of the sympathetic nervous system results in loss of sympathetic tone, venous and arterial vasodilation, decreased venous return, decreased stroke volume, cardiac output, and impaired cellular metabolism. The classic description of neurogenic shock consists of: hypotension associated with bradycardia (absence of reflexive tachycardia due to disrupted sympathetic discharge), warm extremities (due to loss of peripheral vasoconstriction), and motor and sensory deficits indicative of a spinal cord injury, radiographic evidence of a vertebral column fracture.

questions.question: Modified shock index is calculated using?
questions.explanation: • Modified shock index = HR/MAP • Original shock index = HR/SBP The shock index is a hemodynamic stability indicator. In patients with shock, it is a better predictor of mortality than blood pressure or heart rate alone. A shock index > 0.9 is indicative of higher mortality. The modified shock index is a more sensitive indicator of tissue perfusion than the original shock index. In critically ill patients, the DBP decreases earlier than SBP, hence, the modified shock index using MAP is better suited to assess the severity of shock.

questions.question: The peripheral vascular resistance is decreased in
questions.explanation: The peripheral vascular resistance is decreased in distributive shock. It is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in systemic vascular resistance. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in cardiac output. The most common cause of distributive shock is sepsis. The causes of vasodilatation in various types of distributive shock: The following table shows cardiovascular and metabolic characteristics of different types of shock. Type of distributive shock: Septic shock, Anaphylactic shock, Neurogenic shock (spinal cord injury). Cause of vasodilatation: Release of bacterial products (endotoxin) and the activation of cellular and humoral components of the immune system. Histamine release. Failure of sympathetic outflow and adequate vascular tone. Hypovolemia, Cardiogenic, Obstructive, Distributive. Cardiac output: Low, Low, Low, High (in septic and anaphylactic shock), Low (in neurogenic shock). Vascular resistance: High, High, High, Low. Hypovolemic, Cardiogenic, Obstructive, Distributive. Venous pressure: Low, High, High, Low. Mixed venous saturation: Low, Low, Low, High. Base deficit: High, High, High, High.

questions.question: A patient who was admitted with third-degree burns presents with lightheadedness and oliguria on the third day of admission. On examination, the peripheries are warm and capillary refill is brisk. His pulse rate is 138/min. In which of the following types of shock do you see this presentation?
questions.explanation: The given clinical presentation is seen in septic shock. In distributive (septic) shock, the peripheries are warm and capillary refill will be brisk, despite the profound shock. In early stages (compensated stage) of septic shock, the patient has clammy, warm peripheries. The latter is a distinct feature from other types of shock where peripheral vasoconstriction leads to cold peripheries. The patient will have decreased vascular resistance, inadequate afterload, abnormally high cardiac output, and tachycardia. In the later stages (uncompensated phase) of septic shock, there is reduced venous return, preload, and reduced cardiac output with low blood pressure.

questions.question: An 82-year-old man with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections presents with fever, tachypnea, and tachycardia. On examination, he appears confused and has hypotension. Which of the following is used as the initial treatment for his condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of septic shock. Crystalloids are the initial fluid of choice in the resuscitation of severe sepsis and septic shock. Septic shock is also known as vasodilatory shock (but remember vasopressors are not the first line). Management protocol for septic shock: Step 1: Immediate evaluation - securing the airway (if indicated) and correcting hypoxemia and establishing venous access for the early administration of fluids and antibiotics are priorities in the management of patients with sepsis and septic shock. Step 2: Initial resuscitative therapy - aggressive administration of intravenous fluids (IVF), usually crystalloids, are given at 30 mL/kg (actual body weight) within the first three hours following the presentation. Empirical antibiotic therapy started within the first hour. Step 3: Intravenous vasopressors are useful in patients who remain hypotensive despite adequate fluid resuscitation or who develop cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Vasopressor agents such as phenylephrine, noradrenaline are indicated in distributive shock states, which include septic shock, neurogenic shock, etc., where there is peripheral vasodilatation, and a low systemic vascular resistance, leading to hypotension. But they are not the first-line treatment.

questions.question: You are a medical officer at the blood bank and receive several units of packed RBCs, platelets, fresh frozen plasma, and cryoprecipitate following a blood donation camp. Which among the following components would you want to use at the earliest?
questions.explanation: Platelets have a shelf life of only 5 days and hence they have to be used at the earliest. They are usually stored on a special agitator at 20-24 °C. They are given to the patients with thrombocytopenia or with platelet dysfunction who are bleeding or undergoing surgery. Packed cells (PRBCs) are stored in a SAG-M solution (saline-adenine-glucose-mannitol) and have a shelf life of 42 days at 2–6 °C. (Older storage regimens included storage in CPD - citrate-phosphate-dextrose solutions which have a shelf life of 2-3 weeks.) Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is stored at -40 to -50°C, while cryoprecipitate is stored at -30°C, and both have a shelf life of one year.

questions.question: A patient with a history of esophageal varices presents with hematemesis. What is the optimal level of hemoglobin to be maintained in this patient through blood transfusions?
questions.explanation: The optimal level of Hb to be maintained, in this case, is 8 gm/dL. The indications for blood transfusion are as follows: Acute blood loss: To replace circulating volume and maintain oxygen delivery. Perioperative anemia: To ensure adequate oxygen delivery during the perioperative phase. Symptomatic chronic anemia: without hemorrhage or impending surgery. Haemoglobin level (g/dL) Indications <6-8: Probably will benefit from transfusion, 8: Transfusion unlikely to be of benefit in the absence of bleeding or impending surgery. No indication for transfusion in the absence of other risk factors.

questions.question: A 33-year-old male patient was transfused with 2 units of fresh frozen plasma following a road traffic accident. Within 2 hours of the transfusion, he became breathless and his oxygen saturation dropped to 88%. Chest X-ray showed a batwing appearance. This condition occurs due to which of the following?

options.D: Preformed IgM Ab to ABO Ag

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). The presence of antibodies against the Human Leukocyte antigen (Anti-HLA Ab) in the donor blood is implicated in the development of TRALI. TRALI is defined as an acute lung injury that is temporally related to blood transfusion and causes non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It occurs within the first six hours following a transfusion. Screening for HLA antibodies has been introduced to prevent TRALI. TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind to recipient leukocytes. The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. Testing the donor's plasma for anti-HLA antibodies can support this diagnosis. The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. The transfusion of plasma from male and nulliparous women donors reduces the risk of TRALI.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male who is on warfarin prophylaxis for atrial fibrillation presents with massive uncontrolled hemorrhage following a fall from height. Which of the following blood components can be used for emergency reversal of warfarin therapy in this patient?
questions.explanation: Prothrombin Complex Concentrates (PCCs) are indicated for the emergency reversal of anticoagulant (warfarin) therapy in uncontrolled hemorrhage. PCCs are highly purified concentrates prepared from pooled plasma. They contain factors II, IX, and X. Factor VII may be included or produced separately. Fresh frozen plasma and platelets are used in the management of coagulopathy. Fresh frozen plasma is used if prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT) > 1.5 times normal. Platelets are transfused if the platelet count < 50 x 10^3/ul. However, in the presence of non-surgical hemorrhage, these tests take time to arrange and may underestimate the degree of coagulopathy.

questions.question: Cryoprecipitate is stored at a temperature of
questions.explanation: Cryoprecipitate is a supernatant precipitate of FFP (fresh frozen plasma) and is rich in factor VIII and fibrinogen. It is stored at -30 °C and has a shelf life of two years. It is given in low fibrinogen states or factor VIII deficiency.

questions.question: A 22-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. Upon arrival, the patient was unconscious with a blood pressure of 90/64 mmHg and a pulse rate of 139 per minute. He was immediately transfused with 4 units of packed RBCs. All of the following complications can occur in this patient except:
questions.explanation: The complication of massive transfusion includes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. The lethal triad of massive transfusion includes acidosis, hypothermia, and coagulopathy. Other complications that can be seen in massive transfusion are: hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia.

questions.question: A young patient is brought to the emergency room following a motorcycle collision. On examination, the patient is drowsy and has decreased blood pressure due to bleeding from multiple injuries. 1 unit of packed RBCs has been obtained from the blood bank. What is the correct procedure for blood transfusion?

options.A: The blood should be brought to room temperature before the transfusion
options.B: Transfusion should be started within one hour of removal from the refrigerator
options.C: Transfusion of PRBC should be completed within 4 hours
options.D: The rate of transfusion of PRBC is 50 mL per hour

questions.explanation: The transfusion of packed RBCs (PRBC) should be completed within a maximum period of 4 hours after the removal from the blood fridge. There is an increased risk of bacterial proliferation and loss of the function of blood components after they are removed from the storage temperatures. Hence, the transfusion should be started within 30 minutes of receiving the components from the blood bank. The packed RBCs should be infused at a rate of 100-150 mL/hour. Warming of blood is not needed when the transfusion is at normal rates. The transfusion should be completed within a maximum period of 4 hours. Duration times for transfusion: Blood products - Whole blood / PRBC: Start transfusion - Within 30 minutes of removing from refrigerator, Complete transfusion - ≤4 hours. Discard unit if this period is exceeded. Platelet concentrate - Immediately, Within 30 minutes. Fresh frozen plasma - Cryoprecipitate: As soon as possible, As soon as possible, Within 30 minutes, Within 30 minutes.

questions.question: A patient with a road traffic accident presented to the emergency room and requires a large amount of fluids to be transfused. Which of the following IV cannula is preferred?
questions.explanation: Grey coloured IV cannula is required for this patient in order to transfuse a large amount of fluids. The ATLS 10th edition guidelines state that 2 cannulae of at least 18G should be used to gain vascular access in trauma patients. In this scenario requiring large fluid transfusions, the grey (16G) cannula would be preferable to the green (18G) cannula due to the higher flow rate.

questions.question: What is the size of the cannula shown in the below image?
questions.explanation: The given cannula is a 20-gauge IV cannula, as its color code is pink.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of qSOFA?
questions.explanation: Sepsis is defined as a “life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response toinfection." It lies in the continuous spectrum between infection and septic shock.qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infectionwho are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU).•It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for⚫ low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg),•high respiratory rate (° 22 breaths per min)• altered mentation (Glasgow coma scale, <15).38The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple promptto identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis.The primary method to evaluate the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspectedinfection is by determining the Sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score;which includes assessment of:• Circulation Systolic BP & need for vasopressors; platelet count•-Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation• Mentation - Glasgow Coma Score•• Hepatic function - Bilirubin• Renal function - CreatinineOrgan dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ° 2The SOFA score is limited by its requirement of multiple laboratory tests which makes it complexand time-consuming. In order to simplify the scoring process, the "Sepsis - 3" task forcerecommended the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score.SOFA Vs qSOFA :• SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system which is particulary superiorto qSOFA in the ICU setting.•:qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment of individuals at risk forsepsis particularly useful outside the ICU. setting (i.e. ward / emergency department). However,note that it was originally designed as predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsisrather than a diagnostic tool.Thereby, the best description of sepsis based on "Sepsis -3" task force recommendations would be• Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ° 2 Or•Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ° 2Another score that has been used is the NEWS(National Early Warning Score). It ranges from o to20 and is based on respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, use of supplemental O2, temperature,systolic blood pressure, pulse rate and level of consciousness. °5 out of 20 is considered a positivescore.Other scoring systems for sepsis:The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) score is no longer recommended as is itnot specific to infection.The Logistic Organ Dysfunction System (LODS) score is not recommended as it is complex andhas too many variables.

questions.question: All of the following are features of SIRS except:
questions.explanation: Respiratory Rate > 20/minute or (not and) PaCO2 < 32 mmHg (not < 35 mmHg) would be a feature of SIRS (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome). Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) is an exaggerated defense response of the body to a noxious stressor (infection, trauma, surgery, acute inflammation, ischemia, or reperfusion) to localize and then eliminate the endogenous or exogenous source of the insult. SIRS is diagnosed when any two of the following are present: Hyperthermia (> 38 degrees Celsius) or Hypothermia (< 36 degrees Celsius), Tachypnoea (> 20/min) or PaCO2 < 32 mmHg, Tachycardia (> 90/min), White cell count > 12 x 10^9/liter or < 4 x 10^9/liter or > 10% Band forms. Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection.
